job_title: Athletic Communications Assistant in Springfield, MA
pros: Work alongside a great team and learn new skills. You will learn to Input in-game statistical data and visually spotted, stream produce, shot video, and helped maintain historical records and photo archives. This job opens doors to more jobs on the sports media field.
cons: Its a temporary job and minimum wage.

review_title: Room for growth in inclusion and operations
pros: This is a small college so you would get a chance to connect with colleagues inside and outside of your team. If you are an educator who prides themselves on helping first generation college students succeed, this is the place for you to shine. They have been hiring diverse leadership at all levels of the institution so the more this happens, the better it will be for future diverse hires to work in all areas of the college.
cons: When working in my role, I did not always receive support from leadership when I voiced my concerns about exclusionary practices that effected my work performance. I expressed my concerns to HR, but unfortunately, HR was not equipped to handle the situation with individuals in leadership positions at that time. There was not much partnership for creating DEI ambassadors that would ensure DEI initiatives were executed at all levels of the organization. And, I was not supported financially to gain any new professional development skills. As a woman and person of color, I did not see a space for promotion in the organization.

pros: The students and the administration are kind and value learning.
cons: As an adjunct, it is difficult to stay informed, though I have seen improvements over the past year or so.

pros: Great community, free tuition for employees
cons: none its a great place to work

job_title: Assistant Director for Campus Recreation, in Springfield, MA
pros: Strong work community that all pull in the same direction
cons: Occasionally have to pull additional weight.

review_title: What's great is excellent; what's bad is a mess
pros:
Most of the middle management and the employees are absolutely fantastic. The college has a strange knack for backing into excellent young supervisors who have extraordinarily high upside and bring on great people with them. 

Most of campus is very helpful towards each other. You'll rarely get blowback from people when you ask for help and assistance. Depending on the department, it can feel like an incredibly empowering place to work. I was fortunate to be a work hard/play hard office at the college and the team I was with was one of the best i've ever worked with. 

The alumni and students are quirky and certainly non-traditional, so don't expect a very stuffed up, typically academic experience. People are friendly, the campus is gorgeous and in spite of its challenges, can be a great place to work.
cons:
Nearly all of the good things I said above are in spite of upper management; who at this point are a real detriment to the school's ability to move forward. While the school inadvertently finds young managers with talent, they do next to nothing to take care of them, utterly take them for granted and at times actively attempt to credential them into oblivion and ensure they *don't* get promoted. To be honest, it's pretty bizarre. 

The college President is wrapping up his career and is clearly coasting at this point - or at least trying to. There's next to no strategic, long term vision for the institution whatsoever and whatever it is that resembles that is poorly thought out, communicated and executed. The long and short of it is, they're doing everything to balance the books and keep it that way so the next guy can come in. It's frustrating, because the campus has a lot of potential at this point - and every day wasted feels like a day wasted. 

In addition to a President who doesn't seem to really care; the one thing about AIC that really sticks out negatively is their ability to find terrible managers, install them and then enable and excuse their behavior. There are about four actors on campus who are a significant impediment to getting anything done - and display all the kinds of characteristics of people who clearly shouldn't be in those positions on a regular basis. The trickle down effect - whether it be project management, trying to work across silos, the quality of hiring people and culturally is enormous. AIC could be a poster child for being a place where you can actively see the sheer amount of damage a few bad apples can do to an entire institution. Entire projects are nuked, entire offices are chased off and pushed out, bosses not staying in their lane... it's remarkable how much damage gets done; but what's worse is how much is enabled, ignored or excused by top level management.

It's a shame - because the potential at the school is enormous.

Oh and if you want to get paid? Forget it. This place pays well below market level. One manager was pinned down and not promoted until he/she was afforded another opportunity. Then all of a sudden, there was a magical $30k that was offered to stay. How they expected that person to do that and come back to a staff who hasn't received a raise in 2-3 years is something, but they did it. They don't value their best employees and pay for it - not only in terms of productivity but in terms of damaging their reputation in the community.

Now of course, the pay issue is partly what exacerbates what we're discussing above. Good managers won't work at the salary rate the school offers. So they regularly drag out hiring processes longer than necessary (at significant expense to the college), and end up picking people they're not crazy about to begin with - or just flat out garbage managers. It's an amazingly self-defeating cycle.

Compassionate coworkers

cons: location (Springfield, Mason Square), pay, job stability

review_title: If I knew then....would not have taken this job
pros: A number of dedicated students who take their classes seriously and have at least the minimal or above skills to be in college. College has been there a long time and has offered a lot to the community.
cons:
Pay -  Paid only $2400 per class to teach as an adjunct. Far less than I had been paid at a state community college. Took the job only to experience teaching at a private college. Had delusions that it would be somehow better than the community college. It wasn't better; it was worse. 

Skill level of students: Many of the students came with very poor skills. Many did not belong in college.

Attitude and maturity of students: Having been an adjunct for a number of years at a couple of different colleges, I didn't walk in expecting to have classroom management issues.  Many of the students seemed to have the maturity of high school or even middle schoolers and spent the class time jabbering or showing each other stuff on their phones.  Only a handful read the book. (In fairness, there are many students who can handle the work and come to classroom prepared, so I want to emphasize that this criticism does not apply to all of them -- just enough to make teaching at AIC very difficult.  I suppose if I had stayed at this college, I could have adjusted and managed the behavior better, but it made sense for me to  just return to teaching environments where the pay was higher and the students more mature to begin with.

Sports -- Sports is a great thing at the school, but it leaves the students little time to do schoolwork.

Parking. Had to park in a lot down the street and walk. Not the safest neighborhood.
